question: [File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: script_cache and module_storage] [Version Skew] If script_cache caches scripts compiled against module version N, but module_storage is upgraded to version N+1, can an attacker exploit this version skew to cause execution failures or security bypasses? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: both caches] [Transaction Boundary] During transaction execution, are script_cache and module_storage updates atomic, or can an attacker cause partial updates that leave the caches inconsistent across transaction boundaries? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: UnsyncCodeStorage] [Circular Dependencies] Can an attacker create circular dependencies between scripts and modules (script A calls module B which references script C) that cause infinite loops or stack overflows during cache resolution? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ScriptCache::get_script()] [Non-Deterministic Cache Hits] Can an attacker exploit HashMap's non-deterministic ordering in the underlying UnsyncScriptCache to cause different validators to execute scripts in different orders, producing divergent state roots? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: script_cache] [Race Between Deserialize and Verify] If one validator caches a script as Code::Deserialized while another caches it as Code::Verified, can this cause deterministic execution divergence where some validators execute unverified bytecode? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: WithRuntimeEnvironment] [Configuration Divergence] Can an attacker exploit differences in runtime_environment() configurations across validators to cause script_cache to behave differently, breaking consensus? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: UnsyncCodeStorage] [Cache Warming Attack] Can an attacker selectively warm the script_cache on some validators but not others (via transaction ordering), causing performance divergence that leads to timeout failures and consensus disruption? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ModuleStorage] [Module Resolution Ambiguity] If module_storage has multiple versions of the same module, can an attacker exploit cache lookup ambiguities to cause different validators to link scripts to different module versions? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ScriptCache] [Cache Hit Bypass Gas] When get_script() returns a cached script, is gas properly charged for the cache lookup, or can an attacker exploit free cache hits to repeatedly execute expensive scripts without paying full gas costs? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ScriptCache::insert_*] [Verification Cost Bypass] When insert_verified_script() replaces a deserialized script with a verified one, does the transaction pay for verification gas, or can an attacker get free verification by exploiting cache updates? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: script_cache] [Cache Storage Cost] Does the gas model account for the storage cost of maintaining scripts in the cache, or can an attacker fill the cache with large scripts without paying proportional gas fees? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ModuleStorage] [Module Fetch Cost] When scripts reference modules through module_storage, is gas charged for module fetching, or can an attacker structure scripts to trigger unbounded module loads without gas limits? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: UnsyncCodeStorage] [Storage Metering] Does UnsyncCodeStorage track and limit total storage usage (scripts + modules), or can an attacker exploit the separation to exceed per-transaction storage limits? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Function: module_storage() returning &M] [Privileged Access Leak] Does exposing module_storage() allow unprivileged code to access privileged modules or system scripts that should be restricted? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Function: into_module_storage()] [Ownership Escalation] Can an attacker exploit into_module_storage() to extract and manipulate the underlying module storage outside the controlled UnsyncCodeStorage API, bypassing access controls? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ScriptCache] [Cache Injection] Can an attacker inject malicious scripts into the cache through insert_* methods without proper authorization checks, allowing execution of unauthorized code? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Trait: AsUnsyncCodeStorage] [Conversion Attack] Can an attacker exploit as_unsync_code_storage() or into_unsync_code_storage() to create multiple UnsyncCodeStorage instances with different privilege levels, bypassing isolation? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: WithRuntimeEnvironment] [Environment Escalation] Can an attacker manipulate the runtime_environment() to gain access to privileged features or modules that should be restricted to system transactions? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: script_cache] [Migration Vulnerability] During protocol upgrades that change script verification rules, can an attacker exploit cached pre-upgrade scripts that wouldn't pass new verification rules? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ModuleStorage] [Module Upgrade Race] When modules are upgraded on-chain, can an attacker exploit timing windows where script_cache references old module versions from module_storage, causing execution inconsistencies? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: UnsyncCodeStorage] [Cache Invalidation] Does UnsyncCodeStorage provide cache invalidation mechanisms, or can an attacker force validators to continue using stale cached scripts after on-chain module upgrades? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Function: new()] [Initialization Attack] During validator restarts or upgrades, can an attacker exploit the empty script_cache in new() to cause different initial cache states across validators? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation pattern] [Trait Evolution] If the ScriptCache or ModuleStorage trait interfaces change in future versions, can an attacker exploit backward compatibility issues to cause security vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Struct: script_cache persistence] [Cross-Transaction Cache Poisoning] Since UnsyncCodeStorage is not Sync, is a new instance created per transaction, or can an attacker poison the cache in transaction T1 to affect transaction T2's execution? (High)

[File: third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/storage/implementations/unsync_code_storage.rs] [Delegation: ModuleStorage] [Transaction Isolation] Does UnsyncCodeStorage provide transaction-level isolation, or can side effects from failed transactions leave the script_cache in an inconsistent state affecting subsequent transactions? (High)
